text: A Psalm of David. The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
text_kjv: A Psalm of David. The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
text_niv: Psalm 23A psalm of David.The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not be in want.
text_esv: The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
text_nlt: The LORD is my shepherd;I have all that I need.
text_msg: A David psalmGod, my shepherd!I don't need a thing.
text_nasb: A Psalm of David. The LORD is my shepherd, I shall not want.
context: Psalm 23 is attributed to King David, likely written during his reign as king of Israel around 1000 BC, though some scholars suggest it could have been written earlier during his shepherd days. The superscription identifies it as 'A Psalm of David,' and the intimate shepherd imagery suggests David drew from his own youthful experiences tending his father's sheep in the fields of Bethlehem. David's life encompassed both extremes - from shepherd boy to king, from cave-dwelling fugitive to palace-dwelling monarch. He faced mortal danger from lions and bears as a shepherd, from Goliath on the battlefield, from King Saul's javelin and pursuit, and from various enemies throughout his reign. Yet through it all, David maintained a shepherd's perspective on God's care. Psalm 23 is structured as a shepherd psalm (verses 1-4) transitioning to imagery of a generous host (verses 5-6). The first verse introduces the controlling metaphor: the LORD as shepherd. This was radical because ancient Near Eastern kings often called themselves shepherds of their people, but David reverses this - the King of kings is his shepherd, and David is merely a sheep. The historical context of shepherding in ancient Israel helps us understand this verse. Shepherds had complete responsibility for their flocks' welfare - finding pasture, providing water, protecting from predators, seeking lost sheep, and leading them home.
meaning: The theological depth of 'The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want' is profound. 'The LORD' translates YHWH, God's covenant name revealed to Moses, indicating personal relationship and faithfulness. David isn't speaking of a generic deity but of the covenant-keeping God of Israel who has revealed Himself specifically. 'Is' indicates present, continuous reality - not was, will be, or might be, but is right now. This shepherd-sheep relationship exists in the present moment. 'My shepherd' shows personal possession and relationship. Not just 'a shepherd' or 'the shepherd' but MY shepherd - intimate, individual care. Though God shepherds His flock collectively, each sheep experiences personal attention. 'Shepherd' (ro'eh in Hebrew) meant far more than we might assume. Shepherds lived with their flocks 24/7, knew each sheep individually, protected them with their lives, sought the straying, carried the weak, led them to provision. This role required vigilance, courage, strength, knowledge, and devotion. By calling God his shepherd, David claims all these qualities for his care. 'I shall not want' or 'I shall not lack' is the logical conclusion. If the all-powerful, all-knowing, ever-present LORD is my shepherd, what could I possibly lack that I truly need? The Hebrew word 'chaser' means to lack, to be without something necessary. David isn't claiming he'll have everything he desires, but that he'll never lack what he needs. This profound trust recognizes that a good shepherd ensures his sheep have sufficient pasture, water, protection, rest, and guidance. The sheep may not understand the shepherd's decisions - why move from this pasture, why avoid that path, why pass by water the sheep wanted to drink - but the sheep that trusts its shepherd will lack nothing truly necessary.
application: Living with the truth of Psalm 23:1 transforms daily life from anxiety to rest. First, identify yourself correctly - you are a sheep, and sheep are not independent, self-sufficient, or wise enough to navigate alone. This contradicts our culture's emphasis on self-reliance and control. Are you trying to be your own shepherd, making all decisions based solely on your judgment? Sheep that wander from their shepherd get lost, injured, or devoured. Practically, this means submitting daily decisions to God through prayer and Scripture, asking 'What does my Shepherd want me to do?' rather than just 'What do I want?' Second, recognize what you actually need versus what you want. 'I shall not want' doesn't promise luxury or that every desire will be fulfilled. A sheep needs food, water, safety, rest, and guidance - not filet mignon and a luxury barn. Often our anxiety comes from demanding wants rather than trusting God for needs. When you feel lack, ask: Is this actually a need or a want? Has God truly failed to provide what I need, or am I demanding what I want? Third, this verse combats the fear of future lack. 'I shall not want' is future tense - not 'I currently am not lacking' but 'I will not lack.' This requires faith that the Shepherd who has provided until now will continue providing. When you worry about finances, health, relationships, or the future, remind yourself: my Shepherd knows what I need and will provide it. Fourth, understand that 'not wanting' sometimes means the Shepherd withholds what would harm you. A good shepherd leads sheep away from poisonous plants they might want to eat or dangerous paths they might want to take. When God says 'no' to your desires, trust that He sees dangers you don't. Finally, this verse is only true if 'the LORD is my shepherd' - have you entered into relationship with Him through Christ, or are you still trying to navigate life on your own? Jesus called Himself the Good Shepherd (John 10:11-14) who lays down His life for the sheep. Enter His flock by faith, and this promise becomes yours.
prayer: LORD, You are my Shepherd, and I am Your sheep. Thank You for taking personal responsibility for my care, provision, protection, and guidance. Forgive me for the times I've tried to be my own shepherd, relying on my wisdom and strength instead of Yours. Forgive me for doubting Your provision when my wants weren't met, failing to recognize that You have always provided what I truly need. Teach me to trust You like a sheep trusts its shepherd - not understanding every decision You make, but knowing Your character is good and Your care is faithful. When I face seasons of lack or difficulty, remind me that these are part of a shepherd's care, not evidence of Your absence. Help me to follow where You lead, even when the path doesn't make sense to me. Thank You for being not just any shepherd, but a Good Shepherd who laid down Your life for me in Jesus Christ. May I rest in the confidence that I shall not want, because You are my Shepherd. In Jesus's name, Amen.

faqs.answer: No, 'I shall not want' means you won't lack what you truly need, not that you'll always have abundance or comfort. Many faithful believers throughout history have experienced significant material poverty while testifying to God's faithful provision. The Apostle Paul experienced hunger and need (Philippians 4:12) yet maintained that he lacked nothing essential because Christ was his sufficiency. The promise is that God will provide what you need to fulfill His purposes for your life - which may look very different from worldly prosperity. Sometimes financial limitation is actually God's provision, protecting us from the spiritual dangers of wealth or teaching us dependence on Him. The question isn't 'Am I comfortable?' but 'Do I have what I need to obey God today?' If yes, you shall not want.
faqs.question: Does this mean Christians should never experience financial hardship or poverty?

faqs.answer: It might mean you're confusing wants with needs, or it might mean you haven't yet seen how God is providing. Sheep often don't understand their shepherd's decisions in the moment. When led past easily accessible water, the sheep might think the shepherd is withholding provision, not knowing that water is contaminated and the shepherd is leading to clean water ahead. Similarly, what feels like lack to you might be God's wise provision through withholding. However, this verse does require that 'the LORD is my shepherd' - have you truly submitted to His leadership, or are you claiming His promises while living independently? Also, remember that ultimate provision may come in ways you didn't expect. God provides strength to endure what He doesn't remove, provides community when finances fail, provides peace when circumstances remain difficult. The Shepherd promises you won't lack - but the provision might not look how you expected.
faqs.question: What if I feel like God hasn't provided what I need - does that mean He's not my shepherd?

faqs.answer: Jesus explicitly identified Himself as the fulfillment of this psalm in John 10:11-18, calling Himself 'the Good Shepherd' who lays down His life for the sheep. This reveals that David's psalm was ultimately pointing toward Christ. Jesus is the Shepherd who knows His sheep by name, who leads them to eternal pasture and living water, who protects them from the wolf (Satan), and who ensures that none of His sheep will be snatched from His hand. The cross is the ultimate demonstration of the Shepherd's care - Jesus literally laid down His life so we would not want eternally, providing forgiveness, righteousness, eternal life, and relationship with God. When you read 'The LORD is my shepherd,' you can read it through the lens of Christ's revelation: Jesus is my Good Shepherd who died and rose again to ensure I shall never lack what I truly need, both now and forever.
faqs.question: How is Jesus related to this verse as the Good Shepherd?

faqs.answer: The promise of Psalm 23:1 is for those who truly have the LORD as their shepherd, which requires being part of His flock through relationship and submission. Sheep who deliberately run from their shepherd lose the protection and provision that come from following him. If you're in willful, unrepentant sin, you're essentially trying to be your own shepherd rather than following the LORD. That said, God's grace is available to any who return to Him - the moment you repent and turn back, the Shepherd receives you (Luke 15:4-7 shows Jesus as the shepherd who seeks the one lost sheep). The question to ask is: 'Is the LORD truly my shepherd, or am I just claiming His promises while ignoring His leadership?' If you're genuinely trusting and following Christ (imperfectly, but sincerely), then yes, this promise is yours. If you're living independently and claiming God's provision without surrender to His will, you're not actually treating Him as your shepherd.
faqs.question: Can I claim this verse if I'm living in disobedience?
